title: Funeral held for 9-month-old baby Muhammed Saar killed in Syrian mortar attack
text:
A Syrian refugee baby was killed by mortar yesterday in Turkey (Picture: Getty – EPA)

The funeral of nine-month-old baby Muhammed Omar Saar, who was killed by a mortar shell as the Turkish army continued its advance into Northern Syria, was held today.

The baby was one of six killed yesterday during the battles, while three girls under the age of 15 were also among the dead.

Turkish flags were hung from the mosque and coffin as the streets of Akcakale filled for his emotional funeral procession.

Authorities said the mortar was fired from the Syrian side of the border, where its military is battling Kurdish controlling forces.

Mortar attacks have increased significantly since Turkey launched its offensive on Wednesday.

They came in the immediate aftermath of President Donald Trump’s decision to withdraw American troops from the country, after US and Kurdish forces had long been allies.

Muhammed Hani father of Muhammed Omar, a nine-month-old baby from Syria, mourns over the flag-draped coffin of his son (Picture: Anadolu)

People attend the funeral of Muhammed Omar Saar (Picture: Getty Images Europe)

Trump’s move has been criticised by defence experts who said it threatened the lives of Syrian Kurds and regional stability, as well as America’s credibility.

It is viewed as particularly galling given the Syrian Kurdish militia was the only US ally in the campaign that brought down ISIS.

Trump’s withdrawal has been seen as tacit approval to allow Turkey to strike at the Syrian Kurds it regards as a threat.

Turkey’s Foreign Ministry has rejected warnings its military offensive in northeast Syrian would lead to a humanitarian crisis and mass displacement.

A ministry statement Friday dismissed claims as ‘fabricated in order to discredit Turkey’s counter-terrorism efforts’ and only Syrian Kurdish fighters’ hideouts, shelters, emplacements, weapons, vehicles and equipment were being targeted.

Doctors Without Borders said it has shut down a hospital it supports in northeastern Syria, which served more than 200,000 people, due to violence.

Syrians gather at the site of an explosion in the northeastern Kurdish city of Qamishli on October 11, 2019 (Picture: AFP)

An explosives-laden vehicle detonated today in a busy neighbourhood of Qamishli, one of the main Kurdish cities in northeastern Syria, officials said (Picture: AFP)

Smoke billows out in the Syrian border town of Tel Abyad, as seen from Akcakale, Turkey, October 11 (Picture: Reuters)

The ministry also dismissed warnings Turkey’s assault on Kurdish fighters jeopardised the fight against the Islamic State.

A statement read: ‘Those who even refrain from repatriating their own citizens who are foreign terrorist fighters in the ranks of (IS), do not have the right to lecture Turkey on the fight against (IS).’

Turkey’s interior minister said 121 people have so far been detained for social media posts critical of Turkey’s push into Syria.

Suleyman Soylu said nearly 500 people were investigated for posts that characterised Turkey as an ‘invading’ force.
